alright (for context) i have seven groups of sticky notes that i use to document all of my ideas. six groups are for each tangible project idea that i have, and the seventh is a grouping of every random thought that i've had which i can hopefully utilize in some creative way. now, the hard part is that i want to make something from these ideas, but i can't decide which one to use first. this isn't helped by the fact that i constantly get new thoughts and creative ideas every day for each project randomly. how would you deal with this?

first of all i think you might be better off digitally, with computer files. because they are easier to store and manage without making a mess. ok, so, keep updating your 'random' category. this will be your good friend, as you get new ideas. that is fine. there is another job title which is going through the 'random' category, selecting one, and figuring out how to turn it into a more tangible project idea, like the others. What i would suggest to you is this: use a random number generator to choose a number based on how many projects there are, plus 1 for the random ideas category (so currently this number would be 7). i can recommend (ref: https://random.org)random dot org for that. set the range from 1 to 7. (also you must assign numbers to the categories, so you know what the numbers mean). if it lands on the random category (7), then tangify 3 random ideas into actual project ideas, and use random dot org to select which ones from that category to do. then go back and do another random selection again (with a higher number this time, because hopefully you will have added more projects). Here's what i recommend: you must finish the project that is selected. If this seems too overwhelming, then I would recommend doing shorter projects until you are more confident in the procedure. some people are ok with bouncing between projects, but every time i've tried this, it simply turns into a license to escape. so these are my best recommendations

so how are you working around that export issue that prevented you from using blender in the past?

that's already mostly solved. the best way i was able to wrap my head around it is to always export the image sequence to the temp folder. let it overwrite, and as part of the video exporting procedure, i convert the image sequence into a video file, which automatically names itself based on the date and time. an extra challenge is that my preferred software for that sort of thing was quicktime 7 which is also gone. so i am using ffmpeg instead, and i have automated the whole procedure to a single button press using keyboard maestro, which is also what generates the dated file names. i still have no idea how anyone else manages files/exports from blender, but that is the way i am currently doing it. it's worth mentioning that the other tremendous hangup i had with blender in 2016 was the lack of save prompts, and the constant risk of so easily losing the project. but i was thrilled to see that save prompts are there now. and i also used keyboard maestro to get even more robust autosaves

Why is there no b sharp?

because music generally uses families of notes that are not all equally related to each other. the piano, however, uses a full system of notes where each note is equally related to the next, but it's layed out in a way that you can easily skip some of them. the letter names of the notes were based on skipping some of them, because that's generally the trick to getting music to happen. so the spaces in between are called sharps and flats, but like i was saying before, to get that good music sound you wanna skip some notes but not all. and the letters are put on there based on having skipped some notes but not all. so some letter notes are direct next door neighbors (no sharp/flat in between). To explain that in a more real life setting, if you made a system of only 6 letters, with sharps placed between all of them, you would find that playing on only the plain letter keys would produce a very dizzy disoriented sound, akin to a time-warp or flashback scene. but instead the way the letters are actually arranged, this way you can just play the plain letter keys and automatically get something very friendly sounding, like joy to the world, right out of the box

Hey, can you share useful prime factorization techniques?

sure. to check if 7267 is divisible by 7, we can knock off the 7s (26) now we just have to check if 26 is divisible by 7, and it's clearly not because your local multiples of 7 are 21 and 28, not 26. so if 26 is not divisible by 7, we know by extension that 7267 is not either. because to get from 26 to 7267, you have to multiply by 10, add 7, and add 7000. multiplying by 10 will never change whether something is a multiple of 7. and adding more multiples of 7 will never change whether or not something is a multiple of 7. so if 26 is not a multiple of 7, then you know 7267 is not either. congratulations, now you are supposed to check 7267 for 11, assuming you have already checked for 3 which is much easier and i assume you already know how to do

How do you get the courage and express to do the things in your mind? Every time I start I keep thinking "this is not good enough" and stop.

it seems like the fact that you are asking this question means you want to express yourself. so the courage will be there, if that's what you want. the rest is just spending time with it. and remember the golden rule, which is that at every level of experience, even the highest levels, there is a certain element of 'here is a pile of crap, you will like this crap.' what the heck, i do that every day, what with telling people my favorite cereal is marbles. or maybe some people may view that answer as just the perfect answer. at every level of art there is a certain degree of 'World Renowned Artist Presents: Crap.' Look at even the most well respected pieces of art. You can see how they're crap if you put yourself in the artist's shoes. (is anyone going to think this is good, or is it just crap). So go ahead and adopt that mindset early, and that should allow you to have a nice rebellious good time, in the meantime, while you are gradually and unassumingly accumulating genuine experience, which will inevitably happen over time

i don't think you and i have the same process or the same goals musically but i am still curious about your opinion. i'm putting together a set of songs that are basically a religious service like there are liturgical functions for each one except the religion is fictional and this is a sort of alternate universe where everybody knows what to do in this kind of service so it's gotta sound both deeply ingrained and spontaneous so there are no instruments it's all singing, stomping and clapping. the constraint i gave myself to keep this project from taking 8 khgpillion years was that every single first-track take has to be improvised and then i stack more improvising as reactions on top of that track. fastest one (there should be about 16 when i am done, rn i have 5) took 2 hours, slowest one took 2 weeks because the initial improv was both extremely irregular and extremely precise and i had to basically learn it to improvise over and react to it in a  way tha t sounded good to me. FINALLY A QUESTION FOR YOU do you think if you engaged in this sort of improvise-stack-more-no-precomposing-allowed that you'd let yourself get more weird and less polished or would you allow so much re-improvising that it eventually just became a kind of postcomposition? i am having some trouble with the bits of the improvs i don't think are as successful;should i allow chop-ups or is the one-initial-take rule a good one? i thought i could get this done faster if i hobbled my perfectionism by specifying ONLY spontaneous improv allowed, but there are so many ways to elude the spirit of that law and no external deadline requiring i actually do it any faster. what u think

How do I get my work done?

get an audio recording device, press record, get on the computer, learn how to take screen shots if you can't already, and start brainstorming, and type out the list. take screenshots as you go (and say "screenshot" each time you do) so anyone who finds your recordings in the future can follow along with you. why do you upload reality videos years after they are first recorded?

not just upload. select and edit. it allows me to make them better, because i know how the story turns out, so i know which things to choose, knowing what has the strongest relevance. and it also allows me to reveal behind the scenes details without giving away future projects. For example, if i released a reality video using journal audio recorded today, you might (for example) hear me talking about how i am definitely building an animatronic giraffe, and i am very excited about it. Well, guess what, if i release something like that, 2 things might happen. 1 is, i might ultimately fail at building the giraffe and have to abandon the project, in which case it would look very embarassing for me, because everyone would know i failed. And also it might be possible that someone could steal my design for animatronic giraffe and rush to beat me at my own idea. That's a fictional example, but here's an actual example, of a reality video that was released relatively soon after it was recorded -- probably recorded soon after history of japan was released, and the reality video was released probably 3 months later. The subject of the video was about making a music album. I thought, at the time, that i was going to make a music album, of songs. I thought that was a good idea at the time. but since then, i have changed my opinion and now i strongly prefer single songs. So those reality videos talking about making an album look pretty silly now, and they also incite a lot of people to ask "where's the album, what happened to the album", but there is no album. If i had waited a bit longer before releasing journals from that time, i surely would not have chosen the album discussions, and would have gone with something else instead

do you have a keyboard you can recommend for beginner? i thought about getting a fancy one but now i'm considering the very basic, like a baby piano with the colorful keys

the most important thing is this: the keyboard needs to know how loud you pressed the note. Some extremely extremely toy keyboards actually cannot tell the difference between a loud and a soft note, so all the notes sound the same volume. this means that you will sound like a beginner forever, even if you are good. so at the bare minimum, you must get a keyboard that knows the difference between a loud and a soft note. this is called "dynamic sensitive". a simple way to test this is: press a note very quietly, and then press it very loud. see if there is actually a difference in volume. i promise you, if you get a keyboard that does not have dynamic sensitivity, you will sound like a beginner for the rest of your life and not know why
how would you call this chord? G-Bb-Db-F
depends where the bass is
i'd write it as Gdim7, cause you have the G diminished chord and you're adding the minor 7th. however, for some reason ingrained in tradition, Gdim7 usually means G-Bb-Db-E,
right
while i think the chord i want would be called Gm7-5 or something.

yes, in some communities it is called that. elsewhere it tends to be called "G half diminished" which is written with a symbol similar to the diminished symbol (small circle) but with a slash through the circle
this is one of those cases where i just want to ditch the established names and just go with what makes most sense to me, but i'd like to be able to understand when other people write music too.

i would recommend calling it Gm7b5 or G half diminished. i suppose the reason it's called half diminished is because the 5th is diminished and the 7th is not. i think in the traditional view, for major/minor intervals, 'diminished' actually means an additional halfstep flat. so a diminished 7th actually technically is the same notes as a major 6th. none of this is really important unless you like it

hey, just curious if you remember what it was like transitioning into writing the roadmap for songs before you record them, assuming you did it a different way before. like how did you learn?

not really a transition.... i've tried both, and when i don't write it first, it just doesn't have the freedom to go where it wants to go. As i'm saying this now, i can see that it appears backwards, but the reason is because when you're recording a song there are lot of instruments and parts to deal with, so you can't very easily change the way the song goes, on a whim. I've found that it's a much greater advantage when you write the song before anything is recorded, because you can make the song go anywhere, on a whim. you just write it there and it goes there. in other words, writing is not like writing multiple instruments. i don't write the instruments, i write the *song*. which consists of melody+lyric+chords, all the way through, and knowing the exact tempo. The process of translating that into instruments only happens once the song is written. it's probably a lot like animating a cartoon. it's pretty hard to improvise a cartoon. you kind of have to know how it goes before you do it. you CAN however, improvise a cartoon by acting it out, improvised. then based on the recorded improv, make the cartoon. similarly, a song could be made by improvising it using 1 instrument and voice, and then constructing the arrangement based on that recording. i forgot the question

(ref: q.php?date=201912041625)12.4.194:25 pm  please talk more about reality tunnels i keep thinking about them

2 people might look at the same picture, and one person thinks it's "a cat next to a moose", and the other person might think the picture is "a moose next to a cat" ...... our entire world is filled with nano seconds and pixels and colors, ... too many to actually list them all. So in order to actually describe anything, we have to take shortcuts, and make our own simplified interpretation of what we think we saw. when Time is involved, it complicates it even more. because each interpreter might be choosing different moments in time to be the most important. To make any sense of the world at all, we must describe things in ways that we can comprehend, rather than actually listing the location and status of every molecule at every point in time. Because of this, every person may seem to see the world differently ..... not because they actually see or hear any differently, but because when faced with infinite data points, there are infinite different ways to make sense of them, or choose which ones to even look at, and when
